citation.article-title: Syntrophomonas wolfei subsp. methylbutyratica subsp. nov., and assignment of Syntrophomonas wolfei subsp. saponavida to Syntrophomonas saponavida sp. nov. comb. nov.

p.s: Emended description of Syntrophomonas wolfei McInerary et al. [7]
The genus description is the same as that of Lorowitz et al. [5] except that some strains form spores.
In syntrophic association with methanogens, they utilize saturated fatty acids with 4–8 carbon atoms, including 2-methylbutyrate, but not fatty acids longer than 8 carbon atoms.
Isolated from anaerobic environments such as aquatic sediments, digester sludge, rumen digest and rice field mud.
The type strain of the genus is the Göttingen strain, S. wolfei DSM 2245T.
